primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God establishes a unique King-Priest (Jesus) who conquers not through political force but through sacrificial substitution, thereby reconciling justice and love.

tekstueel_bewijs: He’s coming to conquer not just your enemies but sin and death itself.
Jesus Christ was deeply, profoundly, radically, and equally both [King and Priest].
He will triumph. I will save you, but through weakness.

object.identificatie: The satisfaction of God's holiness and the salvation of the hearer.
tekstueel_bewijs: On the cross, God’s holiness is completely satisfied... and yet when you believe in him... you can be forgiven.
The Lord says to my lord: 'Sit at my right hand...'
God treats you as if you were as righteous as Jesus Christ.
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer is positioned as the Receiver of a finished work, though called to respond.

helper.identificatie: The 'Order of Melchizedek' / The Cross / The Holy Spirit (implied as 'power')
tekstueel_bewijs: I’m going to hide you in a rock, and I’m going to put my hand over you to protect you from my glory.
helper.rol_van_god: God is both the Subject (in Christ) and the Helper (protecting the sinner from His own glory).
helper.rol_van_geest: External help that becomes indwelling power.

tekstueel_bewijs: I’m coming to conquer not just your enemies but sin and death itself.
You cannot put me in the box you’re trying to put me in.
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not merely bad behavior but the ontological reality of sin and the 'wrath' of God's own holiness.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The believer, transformed by the beauty of the King, becomes a 'king and priest' to the world.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Serving the neighbor and calling others to repent.
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (ethics) is strictly a result of the primary program (soteriology). The hearer only acts because they have been 'melted' by the beauty of the Subject's work.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.zender_naar_ontvanger: God the Father → Salvation/Righteousness → The Sinner
actantieel_schema_visualisatie.helper_subject_tegenstander: The Cross/Priesthood → Jesus Christ ← Sin/Death/Divine Wrath
actantieel_schema_visualisatie.subject_naar_object: Jesus Christ → Satisfaction of Justice and Love

voorbeelden_god_subject: God puts your sins on him.
God treats you as if you were as righteous as Jesus.
Jesus Christ pays for all the sins.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: You have to surrender to me.

voorbeelden: You have to admit you’re a sinner.
Unless you understand what Jesus Christ did...
Where would I ever get the power to live like that?
I’ve prayed for you, so you will recover.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes that human 'doing' (Devoir) is impossible without the 'power' (Pouvoir) provided by the High Priest's advocacy and the 'willingness' (Vouloir) sparked by His beauty.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from the tension between S1 and S2 (the 'contradiction' in Exodus) to a resolution where both are satisfied in the Cross.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The Cross is the 'admirable conjunction' where S1 and S2 meet without compromising either.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Very high; the sermon insists God *must* punish sin because He is good.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. It defines the human problem as an inability to reconcile God's character and identifies the solution entirely in the person and work of Christ.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: If you're going to deal with me at all... you have to surrender.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: God putting himself where we deserve to be: on the cross.
I’ve prayed for you, so you will recover.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Biblical figures (David, Moses, Peter, Stephen) are used as recipients of grace or pointers to Christ, not as moral templates to mimic by effort.
bijbelse_figuren_als_model: Peter (as a failure restored by prayer)
Stephen (as one empowered by a vision of the Advocate)

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and 'melting' of the heart through beauty rather than pressure.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'Divine King' to the 'Priestly Sacrifice' to the 'Transformed Follower' is logically and narratively seamless.
spanning_punten: The tension between God's absolute justice and absolute love.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: The essence of salvation is God putting himself where we deserve to be.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit (implied) provides the 'willingness' and 'power' to follow.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is so serious it requires the death of the Son to satisfy justice.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God/Christ as the Subject of all redemptive verbs. The hearer is never the hero.

modale_balans.huidige_onbalans: Slightly heavy on Savoir (knowing/understanding) in the middle section.
modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain the current focus on Pouvoir (Christ's power).
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: The sermon already does this well by pivoting to the 'Advocate' at the end.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This is a masterclass in grace-centered preaching. It uses the actantial structure of the text to dismantle human self-sufficiency.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'King/Priest' metaphors, Greimasian analysis reveals that the 'engine' of the sermon is the transfer of competence (Pouvoir) from the Priest to the Hearer.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains Psalm 110; this analysis shows how the sermon re-assigns the roles of the Psalm to the modern New Yorker.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that 'beauty' functions as the 'Helper' that moves the Subject from 'Having to do' to 'Willing to do'.

appendices.notities: The sermon avoids the 'Exemplarism' trap by making the biblical characters (Peter, Stephen) actants of 'Receiver' rather than 'Subject'.
